attributes.heading: What Is the Internet of Things (IoT)?
attributes.markdownData:
A decade ago, having a futuristic home where you could use your smartphone to control blinders or train your thermostat to remember your preferred temperature was sufficient to qualify as a smart home. It's interesting to note that the first generation of smart homes focused more on automation and remote control than intelligence.

Smart home systems have become very popular due to their ability to improve comfort and quality of life. Microcontrollers and smartphones are used to operate most smart home devices. An application for smartphones is used to monitor and control house functions using wireless communication methods.

Let's find out the impact that the Internet of Things has had on Smart Homes.

Defining IoT


The internet of things, or IoT, is a network of connected computing devices, mechanical and digital machines, and objects that can exchange data over a network without requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction.

The term "thing" refers to any natural or artificial object that can be given an Internet Protocol (IP) address and has the ability to transfer data over a network, including people with implanted heart monitors, farm animals with biochip transponders, cars with built-in tire pressure monitors, and other examples.

Organisations across a range of industries are increasingly utilising IoT to run more smoothly, better understand their consumers to provide better customer service, boost decision-making, and raise the value of the company.

Why is IoT important for organisations?


People who use the Internet of Things can live and work more intelligently and have total control over their life. With the help of IoT, organisations can see in real time how their systems actually function, gaining insights into anything from equipment performance to supply chain and logistics activities.

Businesses can automate procedures and save money on labour thanks to IoT. Also, it reduces waste, enhances service delivery, lowers the cost of manufacturing and delivering items, and provides transparency into customer transactions.

Why is IoT essential for Smart Home Automation?


It is now possible to build a smart house that meets and even exceeds the expectations of consumers. The appliances, devices, and sensors in your home continuously record how you use them. They use sophisticated algorithms to identify your consumption patterns and learn about your behaviours. Then, these revelations assist in fine-tuning your experience.

A smart home is one that contains a variety of smart appliances that can automate housekeeping remotely. Also, they could form a single network. For instance, your vacuum cleaner might begin cleaning every day at 11 AM, or the lights could turn on the instant you enter the house.

But when IoT joins this squad, the real magic begins. It gives all of the devices access to the internet, expanding the potential of such a home network. For instance, you can now use your smartphone or computer to see security cameras in your home to observe what is happening there.

IoT applications let you link devices to one another and enable automatic communication between them. Imagine that as soon as your automobile leaves the workplace parking lot, the air conditioner begins to chill your home, allowing you to arrive home after a hot day at a comfortable temperature.

Applications of IoT in Smart Homes


The speed at which technology is currently developing and providing comfort through its services are making every city in the world have smart homes. Here are some of the applications of IoT in smart phones.

  1. Lighting
    2. People can now change the lighting in their homes automatically according to their preferences. The lights may dim automatically when people start watching a movie to keep them from being distracted or the lights may automatically turn on when you enter your home without you pressing a button.

    All of your home's lights may be controlled by your smartphone, laptop, and other connected devices. It would therefore be possible to configure your app to turn on your light when the alarm goes off.

  2. Bathrooms
    3. IoT technology could improve the convenience and fun of your regular activities in the toilet. Smart mirrors can connect to other devices like computers and smartphones, and identify and display relevant information related to family members' faces, including news stories, weather predictions, or certain websites.

    Special sensors can detect movement and turn off the water automatically if no one is using the restroom. Smart shower controls may also identify individuals and set their preferred water pressure and temperature preferences, as well as impose a time limit on shower sessions in order to conserve water.

  3. Gardens
    4. For those who desire to grow their own vegetables, fruits, and herbs at home, sensors are quite helpful. Users can check the app to determine the proper temperature, whether the plant is getting enough water, and whether it is getting enough sunlight.

    Smart irrigation can be controlled by monitoring soil conditions, assessing the amount of moisture in the soil, and turning on irrigation if necessary. When the ideal moisture level is reached, the sensor detects it and turns off the irrigation system. The Internet of Things has produced a significant advancement in gardening that will fundamentally change the way plants are grown in the future.

  4. Kitchen
    5. IoT devices can improve cooking safety and simplicity using AI technologies. To make sure everything is in working condition, smart sensors can keep an eye out for smoke and carbon monoxide as well as the temperature and humidity levels in your kitchen. Special built-in programs monitor the user's food supply in the refrigerator, provide recipe recommendations, and evaluate the nutritional value of meals.

  5. Security Systems
    6. With the help of particular sensors, smart security systems can make sure your TV, computer and other electrical devices are off before you leave your home. These devices can lock the door, close the shutters, turn off the electronics, and make sure your home is secure. Users can check on their homes and control the temperature, humidity, and lighting remotely using the app on their phones.



The Bottom Line


The future of the smart home is already here, and it is changing quickly, thanks to the increased investment in IoT. Today, we can see outstanding connected systems for homes and utilities that save individuals a lot of money, improve home efficiency and comfort, and promote environmental sustainability.

The Internet of Things and artificial intelligence are developing at an accelerated pace, leading to the emergence of a new household, an intelligent environment that anticipates the needs and wants of its occupants and provides them a truly seamless user experience.

attributes.heading: How Can Smart Home Automation Be Helpful For Seniors?
attributes.markdownData:
Think of a situation where you wouldn't have to bother about getting up from the couch to adjust the thermostat or make sure the front door was locked. Although the majority of us take that convenience for granted, elders may not have had access to it up until recently.

The use of smart home technologies is not only beneficial to young people. A voice-controlled or app-controlled home can provide seniors with security, comfort, and connectivity, as well as functionality.

It is possible for elderly people to live independently in their cherished homes with well-being monitoring that is unobtrusive. As smart home sensors observe changes in routine, family members and caregivers can identify and anticipate problems before they arise.

Explore how smart home automation can benefit seniors by reading this blog:

How Smart Homes Can Solve Senior's Worries


Many families find it difficult to provide the level of assistance their seniors need to do so safely and independently. The time we spend with our loved ones is often limited. It might be unsettling to not know what your elderly loved ones are doing during the day.

Having an understanding of the challenges older people face and knowledge of how smart automation can assist them can set a loved one on the path to happy ageing. Therefore, automating your house into a smart home is very beneficial.

Here are some of the ways smart home automation can solve seniors' worries.

  1. Video Doorbells
    2. Suppose your loved one isn't expecting anyone when the doorbell rings. They might ponder whether or not it would be prudent to stand up to answer the door. It might also be harder to see the visitor through the peephole if they have started to shrink or stoop with age.

    Also, seniors are more prone to losing their balance, bruising, and breaking a bone since it causes bones to shrink and muscles to lose strength and flexibility. A fall is not always inevitable, and it is often preventable through knowledge, increased physical activity, and better housing.

    An easy fix is provided by a smart video doorbell. As a result, seniors can use the doorbell's smartphone app to check who is at the door without getting up or unlocking the door, making it easier for them to stay independent. In fact, they are capable of having two-way audio conversations with each other.

  2. Smart Door Locks
    3. Seniors can use a simple voice command or their smartphone if they have a smart door lock if there are visitors. In some circumstances, it is also possible to integrate the lock into the security system so that it locks as soon as the system is activated.

    Or perhaps the door can be automated to unlock when a senior's car arrives after running errands, according to a routine for home automation. A smart door lock's main advantage is the ability for you, a neighbour, or first responders to gain access quickly in an emergency. The ability to unlock smart door locks using geolocation rather than just scheduling is another advantage.

  3. Smart Watches
    4. A smart watch is essentially a small wearable device that is designed to seem like a wristwatch. Touch screen interface is provided by the smart watch, which also offers a variety of possible features like message notifications, GPS navigation, and calendar synchronisation.

    This will allow seniors to be independent despite their difficulties as many senior citizens are retired, and are experiencing significant health problems that interfere with their daily activities. Chronic health problems such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease, or stroke accounts for two-thirds of all deaths each year.

    Smart watches will assist in monitoring the health state of elders with such disorders that require routinely taking their temperature, heart rate, and other vital signs. The smart watch can serve as a fitness tracker, counting your steps, measuring the distance travelled, monitoring your heart rate and pulse, keeping track of your sleep, and even some smart watches can calculate other crucial data you might require.

Why Should Seniors Invest In Smart Homes?


One of the most recent advancements in user-controlled technology is the smart home. They provide elders with greater independence and convenience than ordinary houses can offer. Smart houses are ideal for elders since they serve as contemporary havens. Check out these 5 reasons!

  1. Remote Access – Smart homes connect to a remote centre, such as a phone or tablet, to monitor and process the physical and medical information of elders. They have more independence when they have remote access to house systems like the television, lights, security, and thermostat.

  2. Alarms – A smart house is equipped with advanced security measures. A silent alarm system can be installed with several discrete cameras. There is also the option of connecting multiple devices and enabling user response. For instance, a senior citizen could remotely lock their car doors using their smartphone.

  3. Mobility Access – Smart homes are equipped with robotics and mobility aids to help the physically challenged or the ill move around more easily. And a sensor-embedded device does not interfere with their daily routines.

  4. Medication Reminders – Seniors can set up smart home gadgets to remind them to take their prescription, go to the doctor for a checkup, or remember appointments. A visual component is even included in some drug delivery systems to ensure patients are taking the right prescription and dosage.

  5. Smart Locks, Doorbells and Security systems – Seniors who wish to remain at home can do so with greater flexibility thanks to smart locks, doorbells, and security systems.

    6. A doorbell or lock can keep you aware when your loved one enters or leaves the house. Moreover, they can be controlled remotely by others and offer visual proof of visitors. Caretakers can monitor activity in the house using security systems' visual and auditory tools.



The Bottom Line


Elderly now have more chances than ever to stay active, involved, and connected thanks to smart homes, which are revolutionising how they live. If you are looking for ways to help your loved ones save time, money, and feel safe in their homes, consider automating your house into a smart home.

attributes.heading: What are the 5 Most Commonly Known Myths about Smart Homes?
attributes.markdownData:
The Home Automation sector has grown tremendously over the last three decades. Modern homes have everything from traditional layouts and interiors to modern appliances and devices such as smart control air conditioners, LED lighting, and energy-efficient and cost-saving high-end appliances.

With this shift came the emergence of smart homes, which are home automation systems that are controlled via mobile phones or other networked devices by using various appliances, such as lights, security cameras, entertainment systems, and more. Since smart homes are relatively new territory, some people have misconceptions about their effectiveness, their cost, how they work, and why one should invest in them.

Common Myths about Smart Homes


Many people are eager to dive into the world of smart home automation, while others tend to remain cautious due to previous misconceptions concerning this technology. Therefore, there are some hesitations in introducing it into the home or workplace. The following are some of the most common reservations regarding smart home technology.

By combining next-generation hardware with state-of-the-art software, home automation provides homeowners with complete control over every aspect of their house, according to their individual preferences. Meanwhile, the Internet of Things refers to the connection of any device to the internet and to other devices that are connected to it. An entire network of connected devices collect and share information about the way they are used as well as insights into their environment.

  2. IoT Is Expensive & Installation Is Tedious

It is undoubtedly true that the cost of a custom-built design with only connected devices would be significantly higher than expected if the person were seeking only connected devices.

Through these switches, you can manage individual lights, curtains, electrical appliances and more with a smartphone, tablet or voice control, improving user experience and enhancing comfort on a daily basis. In this manner, you can simply install additional devices as and when they become available. A home automation system with sleek and flexible designs is easy to install and can be integrated into your home quickly and easily.

  3. Users Need to Be Tech-Savvy to Understand Smart Devices


    4. One of the common myths that prevent people from adopting smart technology is the notion that it will be difficult to use. There is no doubt that the vast majority of devices are either wireless or have plug-and-play functionality. Furthermore, if users prefer to use voice commands, adding a smart speaker to the mix can be extremely beneficial.

    After your devices have been connected to your wireless network, you can control your appliances efficiently by following the onscreen instructions. The process of turning your home into a smart home takes as little as a few clicks, despite the fact that it may seem daunting.

  4. Smart Devices Consume a Lot of Energy


    5. Smart devices are not only able to save energy, they can also reduce the amount of energy used. Designed with power consumption in mind, they are energy-efficient and consume little power. By adapting to your behaviour and preferences, they are able to accommodate your needs without having to input a predetermined schedule from your end. As a result, they consume considerably less energy than conventional gadgets due to the continuous study of user insights and patterns. The amount of energy you can save ultimately depends on the kind of device you select and the capabilities of its automation. It is estimated, however, that the systems can help consumers save as much as 10 to 15 per cent on their heating and cooling bills on average.

  5. Smart Devices Consume a Lot of Energy


    6. The possibility of a data breach or the theft of personal information is another concern for many consumers. The majority of companies take extra precautions to ensure that smart devices can't be tampered with, in order to ensure their security and privacy. However, there are a few precautions that can also be taken. By installing encryption on your router and using a secure firewall on your router, you can protect your information. You can secure your cameras and microphones. Whether it's home automation or any other aspect of home improvement, if you plan carefully, you'll feel complete safety within your home.



Myths Debunked


There is no denying that smart home technology is here to stay. Smart home automation systems are becoming more affordable and accessible, unlike when they were considered a novelty or reserved for the extremely wealthy. In recent years, it has become increasingly popular to integrate this new technology into the home as a result of the convenience and security it offers. Professional assistance can be beneficial when it comes to adding smart home technology or updating your window treatments so that they will be compatible with the connected devices you already own.

You should keep these four things in mind before investing in smart home technology:

  2. Discover devices that work with what you are most comfortable with and use what you are already familiar with.
  3. Consult professionals for assistance. The plan for integrating everything together does not have to be complicated, but you'll need some instruction, so use a trusted professional to set up your devices and programs and show you what you need to know.


The Bottom Line


The truth about smart home technology can be distinguished from fiction by taking a few extra steps. Even though it might appear futuristic and intimidating, the easiest way to approach it is by taking one step at a time.It is imperative that you conduct extensive research on the company you choose for your smart home in order to avoid any future inconveniences. attributes.heading: Reasons On Why It Is Recommended To Use Smart Door Locks
attributes.markdownData:
A smart lock is arguably the most important component of a smart home. It not only allows you to easily unlock and lock your door, but it also monitors who enters and exits your home while you're away.

With the use of video technology, a smart doorbell will immediately alert you whenever a guest arrives at your door. Whether you want to check on your visitors or check on your deliveries while you're away, smart door locks help you monitor any danger. Some models simply allow you to open and close doors with your phone. Others allow you to grant special access rights to friends, family members, or maintenance personnel. The most advanced options support third-party smart home devices and services as well as voice commands.

With that in mind, we've compiled a list of reasons why you should consider purchasing a smart lock.

What is a Smart Lock?


A smart lock is a new line in home security, and it, along with Amazon's Alexa and Google Home, is the next step in creating the smart homes of the future. Smart locks secure your home with a digital cryptographic key code, eliminating the need for physical keys, which can be easily lost or forgotten. This technology can even unlock your door for you when it detects that you are close to home by establishing a perimeter around your property, a feature known as geofencing.

Types of Smart Locks


The smart door lock comes in different types depending on the application. Most smart locks enable keyless entry with wireless technology, such as Zigbee.

  1. Smart Lock with Keypad and Combination

    2. To unlock your door, smart locks with keypads require a master passcode. You can also assign different passcodes to different people. There are three types of combination keypad smart locks: keypad deadbolts, keypad deadbolts with a knob or lever, and keypad deadbolts with a handle set. You could use a touchscreen or physical buttons, and many models are easily compatible with other smart home devices.

  2. Locks for Garage Doors

    3. Consider being able to open your garage door remotely for a delivery person — a smart garage door lock can enable exactly this. There are several types of smart locks for garage doors. Many of them work with an app on your mobile device, and you can receive notifications whenever your garage door is open.

  3. Smart Locks with wireless connectivity

    4. Some smart locks include wireless connectivity and can be linked to a smart home hub such as Amazon Echo. These products, which operate via apps such as Syncrow, allow you to lock or unlock your door from anywhere with a wireless connection. You can also keep track of opening and closing times and share e-keys with family, neighbours, repair technicians, and other trusted people. No more duplicating keys and trying to remember who has them!

Smart Locks Vs Traditional Locks


If you plan to get new locks for your house or building, you might be split between regular locks and smart locks. In terms of installation, technology, and integration with third-party products, smart and traditional locks differ significantly.

However, you still need your locks to offer the highest level of protection available today and in the future, despite being familiar with and used to traditional locks. A smart lock featuring the latest technology may be a good option for you as a result.

Traditional locks


Traditional locks were once simply called "locks" before smart locks came along. All things that are not automated and require user input to function are considered manual, and these locks, regardless of style, are not smart locks.

Traditional locks require a physical key, so a person must be present to turn the key and insert it into the lock.

Smart door locks


Smart door locks are more adapted to the modern world, where flexibility is valued. The basic functionality of a smart lock is the same as that of a conventional lock: it allows doors to be locked and unlocked. However, you can also operate the lock using your phone, integrated smart technology, or another smart system since it also has a "smart" element.

What Should You Look for in a Smart Lock?


So the internet of things (IoT) has piqued your interest, and a smart lock sounds ideal, but how do you go about selecting the right device for your space? These are the most important factors to consider when purchasing a smart lock.

  1. Connectivity

    2. When it comes to connectivity, smart locks can be Zigbee, Wi-Fi, or Bluetooth enabled. Bluetooth systems are more vulnerable to hacking, but they also require you to be physically close to the smart lock in order to control it. Wi-Fi systems have more robust security protocols and provide more access; however, many of these consume more power and require constant network access to function. Zigbee systems, which were designed with home automation in mind, are highly secure, use far less electricity, and have a greater access range. To control and manage the lock from your phone, you may need a smart home hub.

  2. Alarms

    3. As with any home security system, you'll want an alarm that will not only deter intruders but also notify you if someone is attempting to break in. Smart locks do not come with built-in alarms, so you will need to purchase one separately. Some smart locks, on the other hand, send automatic alerts, so you receive a push notification if someone unlocks your door when no one is supposed to be home. You can investigate right from your phone if you have a video feed inside or outside your door, such as with a smart doorbell camera.

  3. Keyed versus Keyless

    4. When it comes to installing a smart lock, you have the option of converting your entire deadbolt or simply replacing the interior mechanism. In the latter case, you keep your key for outside access but also have the added benefit of being able to open your door using your phone. However, you are still vulnerable to key loss, theft, or lock picking, and your options for 'semi-conversions' are more limited.



The Bottom Line


Smart locks are one of the best entry points for home automation. They can undoubtedly help those who manage properties, venues, and business locations, particularly when combined with a smart access control solution that allows you to control who has access to which areas and when. They can save a lot of time, money, and effort because of the flexibility they provide.

Smart locks not only outperform traditional locks in terms of versatility and convenience but they are also increasingly being used to improve home security. Because of the rapid pace of technological advancement, many features that were once considered sci-fi in home security are now readily available, which we can all benefit from. Smart homes are fundamentally straightforward. They are made up of one or more intelligent devices that are linked together via a network or the internet. These devices can operate independently or in conjunction with other devices on the same network or under the same account.

attributes.heading: 9 Smart Office Trends For 2023
attributes.markdownData:
In recent years, workplace spaces and their designs have changed, as have our expectations. A workplace design that reflects the changing needs of office workers is absolutely necessary. It is still imperative that office interiors are functional at their core, but employers are increasingly incorporating elements of comfort and features that enhance employee happiness and efficiency.

A smart office is a work environment designed to support flexible and hybrid working. Businesses are incorporating smart offices supported by technology to ensure employees can access in-office resources when they plan to work. The most recent technological trends are assisting businesses in implementing smart offices and moving toward a more employee-led work strategy. Here are some of the most relevant technologies that can be considered when creating a smart office to meet your expectations;

1. Smart Conferencing



Conferences and meetings are now more important than ever in office jobs. The frequency of in-person meetings has reduced recently and hybrid working isn't showing signs of slowing down anytime soon, but businesses must have a well-installed system that supports them now and in the future. A smart meeting room is an essential component of a smart office configuration. Smart technology powers smart meeting rooms, which integrate hardware and software tools into the meeting space to provide a highly productive meeting experience for both remote and in-person attendees.

Employees can host meetings with clients and employees both in-office and remotely in real-time using smart conference rooms. They can also record these meetings for later review, making it easier to keep those who weren't able to attend. Users can now select from a variety of configurations to fit any office or boardroom. The important thing is to ensure that devices can work together to produce high-quality results. A strong system relies on high-quality cameras, microphones, speakers, and screens to allow for better communication from all parties involved. Modern conferencing solutions are designed to work in tandem with well-known software applications such as Microsoft Teams, Google Meet, Zoom, and Skype.


2. Internet Of Things (IoT)



IoT is another promising modern technological trend. Many "things" are currently being built with WiFi connectivity, allowing them to be connected to the Internet—and thus to one another—hence the term "Internet of Things," or IoT. The Internet of Things is the future, and it has already enabled devices, home appliances, cars, and other items to be connected to the Internet and exchange data.

The Internet of Things is already being used and benefited by consumers. For example, when we forget to lock our doors before leaving for work, we can now do so remotely, and we can preheat our ovens on our way home. Businesses, on the other hand, stand to benefit greatly both now and in the near future. As data is collected and analysed, the Internet of Things can improve business safety, efficiency, and decision-making. It has the potential to enable predictive maintenance, accelerate medical care, enhance customer service and provide benefits we have yet to imagine.


3. Smart Desk Management



Businesses that use a hybrid work model frequently struggle to ensure that employees have access to office resources when they need them. The experience of commuting to work only to find that there isn't an open desk could be distressing for an employee. In order to avoid this issue, your company might want to take advantage of smart desk management. Smart desk management is a system for booking desks. Your employees can view the entire layout of their office floor plan by entering the software app. The floorplan will show the office desks, free desks, and booked desks. They can see who has reserved each reserved desk and sit with their team or a friend if they want to book a desk.


4. Smart Presentations



Smart presentation technology has quickly become the new normal for multi-million dollar corporations all over the world. These systems improve employee teamwork by equipping meeting rooms with a growing number of screens. This provides teams with the tools they need to better visualise concepts and communicate them with coworkers, clients, and partners. Users of smart presentation systems can also present wirelessly, using a handheld device such as a smartphone, laptop, or tablet. This not only improves the technology's functionality but also allows employees to work more efficiently and without interruption.

Smart meeting rooms frequently include a smart whiteboard that allows remote meeting participants to view and share information more easily. They connect to productivity and collaboration apps, allowing content written on the whiteboard during a meeting to be distributed to meeting participants after the meeting concludes. This ensures that everyone is aware of what was discussed during the meeting, even if they were unable to attend. Whiteboards are a useful productivity tool for both in-office and remote workers. They can be used to share ideas and visualise a thought process or workflow with the people with whom they are meeting. Many offices have a standard wall-mounted whiteboard or a rolling whiteboard that can be moved from one room to the next.


5. Smart Security



Smart security can help an office in a variety of ways, from remote system monitoring to accurate people management. Using a smart alarm, you no longer need to worry about the last employee who left the building, since you can schedule the security system to set the alarm for the night, and arm and disarm the intruder alarm remotely if you need to. Access control can benefit both office employees and office management. When combined with CCTV, you can visually verify individuals seeking entry to the office or specific rooms within, then grant or refuse entry. Video surveillance can also provide context for accessing events all throughout the building.

Staff can also benefit from an access control solution because they can be given mobile credentials to enter their workspace, which is less likely to be misplaced than an access card. When biometric credentials, such as face or fingerprint scanning, are used, these solutions become even more unique to the user and thus more difficult to clone. The ability to remotely monitor security systems eliminates the need for on-site security personnel to occupy the building outside of working hours.


6. Wellness Verification Software



This feature was primarily used to monitor the health and well-being of the company's employees during the initial outbreak of the Coronavirus pandemic. Wellness verification software is now also useful for effective employee management. Employee mental wellness and employee satisfaction can be difficult to assess when employees are rarely in the office. You can use mental health surveys in conjunction with wellness verification software to determine whether a wellness seminar or retreat is required. With the goal of wellness in mind, the software can also be used to calibrate the amount of light needed in a room based on the number of occupants.


7. Sustainable Office Design



As a society, we are becoming more conscious of our impact on the environment, and this has permeated commercial workplaces as well. Businesses are trying to make their offices more environmentally friendly every day, which has been influencing purchasing decisions. In terms of office equipment, this means using air conditioners, smart thermostats, energy-saving bulbs and high-quality lights that will last a long time. Employers are eager to use sustainable and eco-friendly materials whenever possible, and the number of customers opting for custom-made lighting pieces made from sustainable materials has grown in the past few years.


8. Sound Masking Technology



By 2023, sound masking will be a major office innovation. It's intended to improve workplace concentration by regulating audio levels. It works similarly to white noise in that it raises ambient noise that is specifically engineered to the frequency of human speech, making noise more difficult to understand and thus less distracting. Sound masking does not cancel out all speech noise in an office; rather, it reduces how far away chat can be perceived and comprehended by others. Sound masking, unlike white noise, is intended to be pleasant to the human ear. When properly installed, it should simply blend into the background "hum" of the workplace, with no static, interference, or buzz.


9. Environmental Sensors



Large commercial buildings can pose a number of risks, including VOCs from paints, cleaners, and disinfectants, the use of which has increased significantly in workplaces as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. Access to information about air quality can help businesses protect the health and safety of their employees, lowering the likelihood of liability or an insurance claim. Furthermore, maintaining a healthy work environment in these areas will minimise illness and absence in the office, improving the business's functionality.




To Conclude



Businesses can provide their employees with a smart office that meets their needs when they visit the office using these technologies and trends. With smart technology solutions constantly evolving, there are virtually no bounds to how smart office trends can help you now and in the future.

Smart systems have the potential to improve all aspects of the workplace, from well-being and host desks to productivity, health, and safety. The ability to control lights, blinds, and switches using smart lighting is a great convenience, and provides unequivocal efficiency — you can set times when lights should turn on and off, choose which rooms should be illuminated at certain times, select the level of light that should be emitted, and determine how certain lights react when motion is detected, thanks to its plug-and-play simplicity.

      When it comes to your entertainment system, you can take hidden audio a step further with invisible speakers, which are mounted within the walls and finished with a surround sound system. attributes.heading: 8 Ways How Smart Homes Can Save Energy
attributes.markdownData:
Technology has altered everything in the world – and nothing better reflects our never-ending march toward the future than Smart Home technology, which is becoming more popular and powerful by the day. The concept has evolved well beyond home security systems, activating sprinklers, and detecting leaks in houses. Smart devices can now be configured to perform tasks on your schedule, transmit alerts about performance issues before they become a major problem, and even alter energy usage based on occupancy detection.

Many of the advantages of having a smart home come in unexpected ways - they save energy and heat, making them environmentally friendly and potentially cost-effective to live in. With energy costs eroding household budgets, families are turning to smart home energy solutions to reduce their monthly utility bills. Smart-home devices can help you do exactly this by providing you more control over the devices in your home that use electricity.

But, how do smart houses save so much energy?

What Is Smart Home Automation?


Smart Home Automation is the use of technology to automate your home. Almost every aspect of your home can be controlled remotely with the Internet of Things (IoT). Smart Home Automation began with the invention of the thermostat and has since grown into one of the most important and fastest-growing sectors in technology.

Home security, energy monitoring, personal assistant, and other uses are possible with the use of smart home automation. However, Smart Home Automation more accurately refers to a home in which nearly everything is connected to a remotely controllable network. It allows you to streamline your access to all parts of your home, including lighting, curtains, air conditioning, security, media, health and safety of household users, and locking doors.

Home Automation: How Does It Work?


Through a network of hardware and software interfaces, home automation aims to connect everyday devices via wireless technology. Sensors embedded in each gadget allow you to control them remotely using a smartphone or tablet, no matter where you are. This feature allows you to automate your day-to-day or remotely access your home to, for example, lock the front door, turn down the heat, and control the lights.

Home automation systems consist of three main components: sensors, controllers, and actuators.

  • Sensors can detect daylight, temperature changes, or motion. Home automation systems can then adjust those settings based on your preferences.

  • A controller is a device that sends and receives messages about the status of automated features in your home.

  • The actuators in a home automation system control the actual mechanism, or function, of the system.



How Energy Efficient Are Smart Homes?


The beauty of the way in which smart homes save energy is the convenience of it. They do not restrict your energy consumption nor do they force you to do so. Instead, they analyse your lifestyle and discover ways to conserve energy when and where it isn't required. In the UAE, the domestic and commercial building sector accounts for 78% of the total electrical energy consumption, which naturally draws attention to the need to implement measures to reduce building energy consumption.

Several studies have found that about 30-40% of energy can be saved in a smart home. Smart homes achieve operational energy efficiency by monitoring consumption, providing feedback on when to operate your energy-consuming devices, and being demand response capable. In broader terms, demand response (DR) involves reducing energy load in response to supply constraints, generally during peak demand periods.

8 Ways Smart Homes Can Save You Energy


By providing you more control over the objects in your home, smart-home devices can help save energy and water while also saving money. Read on to discover its true potential.

      1. Smart Thermostats

      With smart thermostats and temperature sensors, you can adjust energy consumption on the fly. According to a smart thermostat study, the average household could save between 10-12 percent on heating and cooling costs. Heat and cooling systems consume the most energy in a home, so those percentages can lead to monthly savings.

      When no one is home, there is less need for heating and cooling, and energy-efficient settings help reduce your heating bill. Smart thermostats can be programmed and controlled remotely using your smartphone, and they will make sure your furnace stays off when you're away, and then warms up just before you get home.


      2. Smart Light Bulbs

      A smart bulb is a light bulb that talks to a wireless network and can be controlled via an app. As with smart thermostats, smart bulbs can be programmed to turn on and off automatically. Some smart bulb brands automatically turn on the lights when you arrive home. In case you accidentally leave your lights on, you can turn them off remotely. When you do not require a bright light from a smart bulb, you also can dim it to save energy.


      3. Smart Plugs

      Smart plugs are a good place to start if you don't have a smart home platform yet. They plug into your electrical outlets and manage the energy consumption of whatever you plug into them. You can schedule times of use, turn on and off power remotely, and view your total energy usage. You can also use it to determine which electrical products and devices continue to consume power even when not in use, a phenomenon known as phantom or "vampire" energy.


      4. Smart Appliances

      Smart appliances like washing machines, refrigerators, and coffee makers are changing the way we interact with our kitchen gadgets. When you leave the refrigerator door open, a notification appears on your phone, and a smart washing machine will alert you if it needs repair. Repairing your appliances quickly can save you the expense of having them replaced. In some cases, your dryer can even tell you when you'll be charged the least amount to dry your clothes during peak times.


      5. Smart Home Security Systems

      You can be alerted of intruders via smart home security systems, and you can even watch a live stream of your property. They keep you safe and can also save you money. False alarms are a common problem with home security systems, and repeated calls can result in fines from your local police department. Using smart security, you can determine if the problem is a real emergency or simply a squirrel running past your security camera.


      6. Smart Sprinkler Systems

      The ability to save on your water bill is another advantage of smart devices. Sprinkler systems with smart weather forecasts use automatic irrigation systems. Watering your lawn synchronises with rain forecasts, which means that there will be no more watering the lawn during a downpour if you don't turn off the sprinklers. You'll also receive water usage reports from smart sprinklers, so you'll know when to cut back on water consumption.


      7. Smart Water Leak and Freeze Detectors

      Often when a pipe freezes or leaks, it will flood a home, requiring expensive cleanup and repairs. The use of smart water leak and freeze detectors can help you stop leaks before they damage precious heirlooms, electronics and personal possessions.

      You can install smart leak detectors under your sinks, around your hot water tanks, or wherever there is water. Even when you are not in the house, you will receive a text or email when a water problem occurs. Early detection can save you money, time, and the hassle of wasting water or replacing soiled carpets.


      8. The “All-Off” Command

      Have you ever accidentally left the television on while leaving home in a hurry? A home automation system can be programmed to turn off or modify any electronic devices still in use. A complete or customised "all off" household feature can be activated in several ways: by arming your security system, signalling a motion sensor, or closing the front door. With the "all off" feature, you can be sure you didn't leave anything on, hence lowering your energy bill.


Benefits Of Smart Home Automation In Terms Of Energy Savings


Cutting your energy use can help you save money on your bills, and smart home technology can help you accomplish just that. Take a look at how:

      1. Prevent energy vampires

      Even if you're not aware of it, energy vampires might hide in your home. When you plug electronic devices into your wall, even when they are turned off, they consume a lot of power. A smart power strip can control these vampires by reducing power use. They accomplish this by turning off power items that are in standby mode, so saving both energy and money.


      Maintain a comfortable temperature

      When the summer heat approaches, it's tempting to turn on your air conditioner to stay cool. This strategy will significantly increase your energy cost, however, there is a workaround.

      Smart thermostats are wirelessly connected devices that automatically adjust your home's heating and cooling temperatures. Typical features include programming your preferred temperatures, creating an optimum automated schedule, offering energy usage data that you can easily monitor, and allowing you to regulate your home's temperature via your smartphone.


      Smart blinds keep the sun out

      During the summer, when the days are long, the sun shines into your home for the majority of the day. Smart blinds can maximise natural light while blocking out harmful UV rays during the warmest times of the day.

      Smart motorised window shades can assist regulate the heat in a room by opening and closing at regular pre-programmed intervals. The blinds will know when to close during the hottest periods of the day, reducing the demand for air conditioning. They are also set to open on bright days in the winter to allow the sun to heat the space.


      Smart lighting control your lights

      When you're in a rush, it's easy to forget to switch off the lights when you leave a room. Fortunately, with smart options, this will no longer be an issue.

      While the initial expense of bulbs may put some people off, they have a longer life expectancy and have been proven to save you money over time. They are also highly versatile, with numerous fascinating customisation options, such as having them turn on automatically with your morning alarm.


      Smart appliances simplify daily tasks

      Smart appliances allow homeowners to simplify their daily lives while also conserving energy.

      Smart dishwashers, for example, expand typical dishwashing capabilities with choices such as voice commands. You may also start wash cycles from your smartphone and track their progress. When a wash is finished or if there is a problem, you will receive notifications on your phone.

      Smart microwaves can do more than simply reheat leftovers. Like dishwashers, you can operate the microwave with your smartphone and receive notifications when your meal is ready.




Are Smart Homes A Smart Idea?


In the face of mounting utility expenses, increased energy efficiency and control is the only way to keep your bills in check. Home automation systems minimise energy consumption and, therefore, household expenses. They significantly contribute to reducing your carbon footprint, which is a practical way to take responsibility for environmental change. Utilising a one-stop "all off" electronics command combined with properly programmed lighting, temperature, shades, and ceiling fans can result in great monthly savings for you and your family.

A truly smart, connected home—one that can autonomously assess and respond to real-time power, water, heating, and other resource requirements—can improve sustainability. At Syncrow, our team eliminates the need for lifestyle concessions through the creative application of state-of-the-art automation solutions. By utilising the latest tech innovations, we offer faster, better, and more convenient solutions that address the needs of global customers.

In Conclusion

The elegance of the way smart homes save energy is their brilliance. They make no attempt to limit your energy consumption, nor do they force you to do so. Instead, they monitor your habits and look for methods to save energy when you don't need it. They are also intended to make the best use of available energy.

attributes.heading: Smart Home: The Future of Smart Living
attributes.markdownData:
Our living environment is experiencing a dramatic transition, aided by smart technologies. Beyond residents' basic practical needs, the rapid growth of technology ushers in a more efficient mode of human-oriented connection to better address the emotional needs of home occupants. As a result, the definition of "living space" extends much beyond physical architecture and interior décor.

Meeting expanding consumer expectations in modern living has never been more vital for industry players, who are now confronted with new prospects brought about by the rise of smart homes. Smart Home automation converts any ordinary home into a fully automated environment that is dependable, scalable, cost-effective, sustainable, energy efficient, and user-friendly. Syncrow also seeks to build sustainability in future smart homes by integrating your home's lifeline, energy, with digitalisation to help you accomplish your carbon neutral goals.

The term ‘smart home’ refers to any home that is automated and equipped with Internet of Things (IoT) devices which are linked to mobile applications. The Internet of Things makes objects and appliances "smarter" and more helpful, and the attractiveness of the IoT-powered smart home in this situation is convenience enabled by automation.



Automating homes includes the integration of everyday devices via wireless IoT data networks through a combination of hardware, communication, and electronic interfaces. In terms of a connected living area, there are five categories to consider: energy, entertainment, safety and security, communications, and appliances. The true promise of a smart home is getting all of those devices to work together effortlessly.

A smart home system can be used to automate mundane tasks such as turning on the lights, locking the front door, or reducing the temperature of any room in the house, configuring and monitoring your home security system and cameras, and operating appliances like your refrigerator or air conditioning and heating with little to no manual intervention after setup.

How Does Home Automation Work?

It is becoming increasingly common to build smart homes from the start of the construction process, but technically, any home with an internet connection and an IoT device can be considered a smart home. Syncrow uses Zigbee, a specification that has existed for over a decade and is widely regarded as an alternative to Wi-Fi and Bluetooth for various applications such as low-powered devices that do not require a lot of bandwidth. Advanced protocols such as Zigbee, compared to the internet, are not hackable and do not create traffic on the router.

A home automation system consists of three main components: sensors, controllers, and actuators.
  • A sensor can detect changes in daylight, temperature, or motion. You can then customise these settings (and more) to your desired preference with a home automation system.
  • Controllers are the computers, tablets, or smartphones that are used to transmit and receive messages regarding the state of automated systems in your house.
  • An actuator is a device that controls a home automation system's mechanism, or function, such as a light switch, a motor, or a motorised valve. Activation is pre-programmed or controlled remotely via a controller.


Setting up your smart home is easier than ever, but selecting the proper smart home system to integrate your devices and have them connected to each other is a major decision.

What Is An Ideal Smart Home?

A smart home integrates traditional home systems into a smart yet sustainable environment that prioritises health, safety and security, energy and water savings, and, most importantly, the home owner's comfort. Devices in a smart home are interconnected via wireless IoT data networks, allowing the user to automate features such as home security, heating, lighting, and a home theatre. Therefore, instead of operating appliances, thermostats, lighting, and other functions with many devices, homeowners can manage them all with a single device—typically a smartphone or tablet.

There is no limit to the convenience that smart homes can provide for their users. After a hard day’s work, users can come home to a garage that automatically opens for them upon arrival, a house programmed to be the most comforting temperature, the lights turned on so they don’t have to walk into a dark house all while their favourite music lightly drifts throughout the house.

Consumers can also improve their efficiency with home automation. Smart home systems can learn homeowners' behaviour and cool the house before they arrive home after work rather than leaving the air conditioner running all day. It is the same with appliances. Smart irrigation systems will water the lawn only when it is necessary and with the right amount of water. It can help save both natural resources and money for the consumer by making energy, water, and other resources more efficient.

Benefits of a smart home include:


      01. Remote access
      Being able to integrate all of your house's technology through a single interface is a huge step forward for technology and home management. In theory, all you'll need to do is learn how to use one app on your smartphone or tablet to access a plethora of functions and gadgets around your home. For new users, this significantly reduces the learning curve and makes it easier to achieve the functionality that they really want.


      02. Flexibility
      When it comes to accommodating new devices, appliances, and other technology, smart home systems are famously adaptable. You'll most likely add to your gadget arsenal as you replace older ones or discover new technologies to complement your indoor and outdoor environments. Being able to easily integrate these newcomers will make your job as a homeowner much easier and will allow you to continue effortlessly updating to the latest lifestyle technologies.


      03. Energy efficiency
      It is possible to make your room more energy-efficient depending on how you use your smart-home devices. For example, a programmed smart thermostat that learns your schedule and temperature preferences and then suggests the optimum energy-efficient settings throughout the day can provide you with more exact control over your home's heating and cooling.


      04. Convenience
      The convenience of setting your devices’ functionality on schedules, synchronising with sunrises and sunsets, or even controlling them remotely, cannot be overstated. End users benefit from the convenience of home automation because rote tasks are handled automatically. In order to automate regular home processes, you can set triggers between a variety of smart gadgets that are compatible with one another.


      05. Safety
      Security and safety are the primary reasons consumers purchase smart devices. Several smart security products can increase your home's security, such as sensors for doors and windows, video doorbells with web access, and security cameras that detect people. The same motion sensors that help you to enter doors and walk through hallways after dark can be automated to trigger automatic lighting to deter burglars. Security cameras allow on-site or remote monitoring of package deliveries, as well as real-time video surveillance of residents or unwanted visitors.


What Is The Future Of Smart Homes?


Because of the overwhelming customer interest in smart home technology, the world's largest tech companies and entrepreneurs have launched a race to outdo one another. That means that bigger, better smart home equipment is continually being developed to meet our digital needs, and the industry is on a meteoric rise.

  • Interoperability will be the norm
    There are many disparate smart home systems that operate on different protocols and share different types of data. We are still far from the dream of seamless, connected homes despite the proliferation of devices. Consider entertainment, utilities - such as heating, lighting, irrigation, and security - on a holistic scale.

  • Small steps will make a big impact
    Sensors and IoT devices will get smaller, less power-consuming, and longer-range in the smart home in order to track and alert when things look out of the ordinary. In the smart home, data will not always need short-range, uninterrupted, high-frequency connectivity - which means data is truly "everywhere."

    Rather than high-bandwidth data dumps, there will be solutions that benefit from a continuous "pulse" of data - small packets moving quickly and having a large impact. It is predicted that connectivity technology that consumes more energy and power will be restricted to specific applications such as video streaming, television and gaming, in addition to enabling remote-first work policies.

  • IoT as a catalyst for good
    In addition to providing a gateway for other smart home applications, smart home penetration strengthens the opportunity for IoT to spark social and environmental change. Connected consumers tend to be conscious consumers. There are also many homeowners already making steps toward being better stewards of the communities in which they live in, and that stewardship can extend to the home as well. This can be achieved for consumers through connected IoT devices, such as pay-as-you-drive insurance or incentives designed for electric and green vehicles.



When it comes to the current position of the industry in UAE as of 2022, the Smart Home market is expected to generate US$60.07m in revenues. A projected market volume of US$96.57m is expected by 2026, resulting in an annual growth rate of 12.60%. By 2026, there will be 0.4 million active households in the Smart Home market.

As consumers gain control over their homes, footprints, and impacts on the communities in which they live, a ripe market opportunity continues to open up. Smart homes are closer to becoming reality thanks to IoT-powered devices that are low-power, long-range, and cost-effective.
